title: 10 Home Hacks for Removing Stickers from Any Wood Surface

steps.title: Hover a dryer or heat gun over the sticker on its lowest setting.
steps.content: Hover a dryer or heat gun over the sticker on its lowest setting. Hold the blow dryer or heat gun two inches (5 cm) over the sticker for about 30 seconds. [1] X Research source Scrape the edge of the sticker with an old plastic credit card or plastic putty knife . Keep heating and scraping the sticker until you can peel it off the wood surface. Alternatively, use a palette knife or a plastic butter knife to scrape the sticker off. If the sticker doesn't come right off, grab the edge with tweezers or needle-nose pliers and pull the sticker as you heat the underside with the hair dryer. Try not to heat the wood for more than 30 seconds at a time. Too much heat can damage the finish or cause the sticker to leave a stain.

steps.title: Soak a cotton ball with oil and apply it to the sticker.
steps.content: Soak a cotton ball with oil and apply it to the sticker. Apply a few drops of a vegetable or plant oil (like eucalyptus , canola, or olive oil) or low-strength mineral oil (like baby oil ) on a cotton ball and dab it on the sticker. Let the oil sit for 1 to 2 hours, then pry the sticker off the wood surface with a plastic scraper. Wipe away the excess oil with a cloth. [2] X Research source Unfinished woods might absorb the oil and darken—this isn't harmful, but if you don't want your furniture to potentially change color, try another method. Use lemon oil on gentle wood surfaces like guitar fretboards. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Apply the acetone with a cotton ball, then scrape the sticker off.
steps.content: Apply the acetone with a cotton ball, then scrape the sticker off. House cleaning professional Raymond Chiu says to gently “Apply the nail polish remover with a cotton [ball ] on the adhesive and allow it to sit for [3 to 5] minutes. Then, use a scraper to lift the adhesive off the wood. Repeat the process as necessary until all the adhesive is off the wood.” Chiu says “Be careful not to apply the nail polish remover on the wood and have a dry clean cloth in hand just to wipe away any excess liquid if necessary.” Use a gentle scraper like a plastic putty knife or an old credit card to make sure it doesn't scratch the wood's surface.

steps.title: Soak a cloth in white distilled vinegar and lay it over the sticker.
steps.content: Soak a cloth in white distilled vinegar and lay it over the sticker. Let the vinegar absorb into the sticker for 3 to 5 minutes, then gently peel the sticker off with a plastic scraper or your fingernail. Repeat if necessary to remove the sticker and all the leftover adhesive. [4] X Research source Alternatively, soak a cloth in warm water and lay it directly over the sticker. Let it sit for 5 minutes, then remove and scrape off the sticker. This can also remove stickers from glass and ceramic surfaces, like the backs of plates and jars. [5] X Research source After you're done, protect and wipe down the surface with wood polish .

steps.title: Gently remove sticker residue with petroleum jelly.
steps.content: Gently remove sticker residue with petroleum jelly. Spread the petroleum jelly directly over the sticker or sticky residue and let it sit overnight. The next day, use a plastic scraper or your fingernail to gently pry the sticker and its adhesive off the wood surface. [6] X Research source Petroleum jelly can also fix minor scratches, stains, and water rings on wood furniture. Just cover the area with the jelly, let it sit for 24 hours, and wipe away the excess with a cloth. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the wood with a microfiber cloth dipped in soapy water.
steps.content: Scrub the wood with a microfiber cloth dipped in soapy water. Combine a few drops of dish soap with 1 cup (240 mL) of warm water, dip a microfiber cloth in the mixture, and gently scrub at the sticker. Rinse and repeat, until all the residue is gone. [8] X Research source Once the sticker is completely removed, wipe the area with a clean dry microfiber cloth.

steps.title: Apply a product like Goo Gone or Goof Off and peel off the sticker.
steps.content: Apply a product like Goo Gone or Goof Off and peel off the sticker. Try a product like Goo Gone Sticker Lifter , Goof Off , or 3M General Purpose Adhesive Cleaner and follow the instructions on the back. Most products will ask you to apply the product directly to the sticker, wait for a few minutes, and use a plastic scraper to pry the sticker off. [9] X Research source Alternatively, use a small paint brush to apply naphtha to the edge of the sticker. Scrape the sticker up, applying more naphtha to the underside as you peel. [10] X Research source Read the label instructions to make sure the product is safe for wood. Most of these solvents are only safe on finished and painted wood. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub at the sticker with a rubber eraser to remove it.
steps.content: Scrub at the sticker with a rubber eraser to remove it. A rubber eraser can remove sticker residue from many surfaces, including wood. [12] X Research source Just grab any pencil eraser and scrub at the sticker until it starts to peel off. Continue rubbing until all the sticky adhesive is gone. [13] X Research source Use a damp cloth to wipe away any leftover eraser shavings.

steps.title: Apply rubbing alcohol to stickers on unfinished wood surfaces.
steps.content: Apply rubbing alcohol to stickers on unfinished wood surfaces. Rubbing alcohol can strip away the finish on painted, varnished, and finished wood surfaces, so it may be best to only use this on raw wood. [14] X Research source Wet a paper towel or cotton ball with rubbing alcohol, dab the sticker, and let it sit for 3 to 5 minutes. Scrape off the sticker with a plastic scraper. [15] X Research source To remove leftover residue, rub the spot with more rubbing alcohol until it's gone. Make sure to test the rubbing alcohol on an unseen corner of the wood to make sure it won't damage the surface while trying to remove the sticker.

steps.title: Sand the sticker off unfinished wood if no other method works.
steps.content: Sand the sticker off unfinished wood if no other method works. If the sticker or sticker residue will not come off on your unfinished wood furniture, sand the entire surface with 100-grit sandpaper . Restore the smooth surface with 120-grit sandpaper , then 220-grit . [16] X Research source If you want to sand down a finished or painted piece of wood, make sure to reapply whichever finish or paint was used to restore it fully.
